For details, please review the description at the beginning of surah al-Baqarah volume I "The Qur'an and its commentary" with the title "Fawatihus Suwar".

In this verse Allah explains that the Qur'an was sent down not to cause trouble and harm. For the Prophet Muhammad, this verse is as entertainment. It was emphasized that the Qur'an was sent down to him not to make it difficult, nor to be forced on stubborn people, but the Qur'an was sent down to him to be conveyed to his people and to be a warning to them about his misguided actions. If the task of the Prophet Muhammad has been carried out and his da'wah has been carried out, but his people are still disobedient and do not want to obey him, then it is left to Allah, because the Prophet's obligation is only to convey what is his duty, as Allah says: So if they turn away, then know the obligation that is imposed upon you (Muhammad) is only to convey (the message of Allah) clearly. (an-Nahl/16: 82) Therefore, the Prophet Muhammad did not need to feel anxious, let alone destroy himself because humans did not want to follow his call, as Allah described in His words: Then perhaps you (Muhammad) will harm yourself because grieve after they turn away, if they do not believe in this information (Al-Qur'an). (al-Kahf/18: 6) Likewise the Prophet Muhammad did not need to feel difficult in conveying the Qur'an to humans, as Allah said: (This is) the Book that was sent down to you (Muhammad); so do not be short of breath over it, so that you may warn with it (the Book) and become a lesson for those who believe. (al-A'raf/7: 2) Al-Qurthubi explained about Umar bin al-Khaththab's conversion to Islam, at that time Umar bin al-Khaththab entered the house of his brother-in-law Sa'id bin Zaid, he was reading surahh Thaha with his wife Fatimah bint al-Khatthab (Umar's younger brother), and Umar asked for it but was not given it so he got angry and seized the manuscript. When Umar read it, soft and soft heart to accept Islam.

In this verse Allah explains that the Qur'an was revealed to be a warning and a lesson for humans. God-fearing man will immediately accept it and make use of the warnings and lessons for him. Whereas a person who does not fear Allah, because his soul is frozen, has a heart as hard as a rock or even harder, will not leave the slightest trace of the warnings and lessons contained in the Qur'an on him. They are as if deaf, mute and blind without reason, like other creatures. They will be put into hell later. As mentioned in the word of God: And indeed, We will fill Hell with many from among the jinn and humans. They have hearts, but they do not use them to understand (the verses of Allah) and they have eyes (but) they do not use them to see (signs of Allah's power), and they have ears (but) they do not use them to hear (the verses of Allah) ). They are like livestock, even more astray. They are the ones who are heedless. (al-A'raf/7: 179)

In this verse Allah explains that the Qur'an which was brought by the Prophet Muhammad came from Allah, the God who created nature, the Almighty for all that He wills. He is the one who created the earth and all that is in it. He is the one who created the vast sky and everything in it.

In this verse Allah explains that the Creator of the heavens and the earth is the Most Gracious One who resides on the Throne. Allah resides on the 'Throne, never to be described as like a king sitting on his throne, because to describe like that, means to have likened the Khaliq to His creatures. Such an assumption is totally not justified by Islamic teachings, in accordance with the word of Allah: There is nothing similar to Him. And He is All-Hearing, All-Seeing. (asy-Syura/42: 11) Ibn Kasir said in his book of commentary, that the best way to understand this verse is the way that has been taken by the Ulama of the Salaf, namely believing in the expression as stated above 'Arsy (sitting on the throne) but the way or kaifiat (sitting on the throne) should not be equated with the way a creature sits, such as someone sitting on a chair. It is entirely the authority of Allah alone, humans cannot know its essence.

In this verse Allah explains that all that is in the heavens, on earth, between the heavens and the earth, as well as everything that is in the ground, both what is known and what is not known belongs to Allah. It is He who rules over all, and arranges as He wills. He is the Knower of all that exists, both the unseen and the real. Nothing moves, remains motionless, changes, remains, and so on except with His permission, according to His divine nature. Allah's Word: To Allah belongs whatever is in the heavens and whatever is on the earth. If you reveal what is in your heart or hide it, Allah will take it into account (about that deed) for you. He forgives whom He wills and punishes whom He wills. Allah is almighty over all things. (al-Baqarah/2: 284)

This verse explains that when saying a prayer or remembrance, it is not necessary to say it out loud. To Allah it is the same whether it is loud or not. Allah knows what is kept secret as well as what is more hidden than that secret, such as a whisper in the heart, or something that crosses the mind. Prayers and remembrance are said with the tongue only to express what is in our hearts. Allah said: And keep your words secret or reveal them. Indeed, He is All-Knowing of all the contents of the heart. (al-Mulk/67: 13) In line with this verse, Allah says: And remember your Lord in your heart with humility and fear, and by not raising your voice in the morning and evening, and do not be of those who are heedless. (al-A'raf/7: 205)

Allah who sent down the Qur'an is the Creator and Owner of this world, therefore the truth of the Qur'an is beyond doubt. Allah is Almighty and where humans ask. To call Him, Allah has many names. All names are good, because they refer to His perfection, might and majesty. However, His substance remains, not enumerated. In a mutawatir hadith, it is stated that Allah has 99 names. Word of the Prophet Muhammad saw: Verily Allah has 99 names, one hundred minus one. Whoever memorizes it (adapts it) will enter paradise. (Al-Bukhari and Muslim from Abu Hurairah) It is narrated that when Abu Jahl heard the Prophet Muhammad in his exclamation saying, "O Allah! O Rahman!" Abu Jahl said to Walid bin Mugirah, "Muhammad forbade us to call on Allah with another God, even though he himself called on Allah with Ar Rahman." Then came the verse which confirms that Allah has many names, as Allah says: Say (Muhammad), "Call on Allah or call on Ar-Rahman. With whichever name you can call, because He has the best names (Asma' ul husna) and do not raise your voice in prayer and do not (also) lower it and try to find a middle way between the two.". (al-Isra'/17: 110)

In this verse, Allah begins the story of Prophet Musa as with an expression as if asking the Prophet Muhammad, did the events and stories of Prophet Musa reach him when preaching to his people? Such a method is usually done to focus attention, in this case the attention of the Prophet Muhammad and also his people on what will be conveyed. It has become the custom of the Arabs, when a news or story is to be presented, it is preceded by an expression in the form of a question, to attract attention so that listeners follow the news or story with great attention.

After the end of the contract period, Musa tended Sheikh Madyan's goats, as a dowry that Musa had to pay to his in-laws in Madyan, he asked permission to return to Egypt, to meet his mother who had been abandoned for more than ten years. After obtaining permission, Musa went with his family to Egypt, avoiding the usual roads and taking the road on the slopes, for fear that his family would be disturbed by the king of Syria. In the tafsir of ar-Razi and al-Qurthubi it is stated that after arriving in the Tuwa valley to the west of Mount Tursina, his wife gave birth to a child, on a pitch black, cold night and was lost. In order to warm the bone-chilling cold and get light in the pitch darkness, Musa (as) tried to find fire, but his efforts were not successful. Then unexpectedly, he saw fire from afar on the left side of the road. So he said to his family happily, "You guys stay here first, I saw the fire from afar, and now I'm going there. Hopefully I can bring the fire here, or get directions from it, to get out of the way." this is our way." Events like these, are also related in other verses in the Qur'an, as Allah says: So when Musa had finished the appointed time and he set out with his family, he saw fire on the mountainside, he said to his family, " Wait (here), actually I see a fire, hopefully I can bring you some news from (place) the fire or (bring) a spark of fire, so you can warm yourself." (al-Qashash/28: 29)

When Musa (as) arrived at the place of the fire, he saw the fire shining white and clean around a green tree. Musa was amazed to see this incident, because the pure white light of the fire did not reduce the green color of the tree, and vice versa, the green color of the tree did not reduce the white light of the fire. It was at that time that Musa (as) heard a voice calling, "O Musa."

Hearing the call, Musa was surprised and doubted, where did the voice come from. The calling voice was followed later by a voice, which stated that Allah is the God who has created human beings perfectly, then the voice asked him to take off his two sandals because he was in a valley called "thuwa", a sacred and highly respected valley.

In this verse Allah explains that He has chosen and appointed Musa as a prophet and apostle and then he is asked to listen to the revelations that will be conveyed to him. In line with this verse the word of God: (God) said, "O Musa! Truly I chose (preferably) you over other human beings (in your time) to carry My message and My word., therefore hold fast to what I give to you and be among the grateful." (al-A'raf/7: 144)

In this verse Allah explains that the main revelation and what is conveyed is that there is no true God but Allah and there is no partner for Him, to instill a sense of monotheism, oneness of Allah, confirming confession accompanied by belief and proven by deeds. Therefore only He is the only one who must be worshiped, obeyed His rules. This monotheism, is the essence of all that is essential, and this monotheism is also the first obligation and must be taught first to humans, before other religious lessons. At the end of this verse Allah emphasizes that prayers should be established. Of course, pray in accordance with His commands, complete with its pillars and conditions, to remember Allah and pray to Him sincerely. Salat is mentioned here specifically, to show the superiority of the prayer service compared to other obligatory worship services, such as fasting, zakat, pilgrimage and others. The virtues of praying, among other things, are that when it is carried out as well as possible, in accordance with the rules that have been outlined for it, it will prevent a person from committing heinous and unjust acts, as Allah says: Read the Book (Al-Qur'an) that has been revealed to you (Muhammad) and pray. Verily prayer prevents from (deeds) abominable and unjust. And (know) the remembrance of Allah (prayer) is greater (its priority than other acts of worship). Allah knows what you do. (al-'Ankabut/29: 45) Some Tafsir experts are of the opinion that the conclusion of this verse, is addressed to people who do not perform their prayers on time, whether due to forgetfulness or otherwise, so that they carry them out when they are aware and remember Allah's abandoned command as the words of Rasulullah saw. Whoever sleeps from the prayer or forgets, then his compensation (gafarat) is the prayer when he remembers. There is no other balance besides that. (Al-Bukhari and Muslim from Anas bin Malik) And he also said: If one of you sleeps so he doesn't pray or forgets to pray, let him perform it when he has remembered it, because Allah says, "And pray in remembrance of Me." (Al-Bukhari and Muslim history from Anas) One of the functions of prayer is to remember Allah, but that does not mean that it is permissible not to pray, it is enough just to remember Allah, because dhikr is done with the heart, mouth and limbs.

In this verse Allah explains that the Day of Judgment will definitely come, but Allah deliberately keeps it secret and does not explain when the Doomsday will occur. Allah deliberately kept the time of the Day of Judgment a secret so that humans would always be careful and alert and ready to face it. Concealing the arrival of the Day of Judgment is the same as concealing when someone's death will come. No man knows when or where he will die, as Allah says: And no one can know on what earth he will die. (Luqman/31: 34) If a person knows when his death will come, of course he will do whatever he wants, follow his desires, do all kinds of immorality that he wants. After his death is near then he repents and Allah will accept his repentance according to His promise. Allah will not break His promise, as His word: Truly, Allah does not break promises. (Ali Imran/3: 9) But if he does not know when his death will come, of course he is always careful, he carries out orders, avoids prohibitions. If he commits immorality, he immediately repents for fear that his death will come suddenly before he repents. So, the purpose of keeping the doomsday a secret is so that people are active in doing good, if a human who is supposed to do good does evil, then that person deserves to be punished. Therefore it is very fair if those who do good are rewarded and those who do evil are punished. Allah's Word: So whoever does an atom's weight of good, surely he will see (reply) it, and whoever does an atom's weight of evil, surely he will see (reply) it. (az-Zalzalah/99: 7-8) And His words: Indeed, you are only rewarded for what you have done. (ath-thur/52: 16)

Even though this verse is addressed to Prophet Musa as, it is a lesson for Muslims. Allah asks that we are not influenced by people who do not believe in the Last Day and people who only follow their desires. If we follow the wishes of those people, then we will lose and regret. Wealth, luxury will not be able to help us from Allah's punishment, as Allah says: "And his wealth is of no use to him when he has perished." (al- Lail/92: 11) Also our family will not be able and may help as Allah says: On that day man will flee from his brother, and from his mother and father, and from his wife and children. Every one of them that day had some business to occupy him with. ('Abasa/80: 34-37)

In this verse it is explained that Allah asked the Prophet Musa as, what was in his right hand, even though Allah knew it; the intention is to explain that the stick made of wood which in essence has no important meaning and many benefits will be made by Him an object that has great advantages and benefits that never crossed his mind, namely as a miracle for him. The stick can become a big snake, and when it is hit into the sea, the sea will split open and when it is hit against a rock, water will emit water with Allah's permission. These incidents show the perfection, power and greatness of Allah.

In this verse Allah explains the answer of Prophet Musa as to His question that, "The stick that he used to lean on, when he was walking or when he was tired, dropped leaves for his goats to eat, and many other needs, such as carrying provisions to drive away wild beasts that would eat his goats. Musa's answer was finally cut short by saying, "And I have some for my other needs," because he hoped that his conversation with his Lord would last longer, and to maintain good manners before God because of the possibility there is another question from God.

After the Prophet Musa answered God's question about the function of the staff he held, including supporting his body, driving his animals, and other functions that help with his daily work. So Allah wanted to show Prophet Musa another function of his stick that Prophet Musa had never imagined. The stick became a miracle that would prove his prophethood and help his function as a prophet. Allah ordered Prophet Musa to throw his stick.

As soon as Moses fulfilled God's command, his stick turned into a big scary snake, crawling agilely from one place to another, just like a small nimble snake, seeing this fact Prophet Musa was scared, intending to run away, but due to so much fear, he only fixed where he stood, as Allah said: And throw your staff!" Do not be afraid! Truly in My presence, the apostles have nothing to fear. (an-Naml/27: 10)
Because Moses was afraid, God ordered Prophet Musa to catch the snake without hesitation and fear, because the big snake that was in front of him would be restored to its original shape as a staff.

In this verse, Allah ordered Musa (as) to insert his right hand from his sleeve and place it under his left armpit, so that when he removes his hand, it will become pure white, shining and without the slightest blemish. This was the second miracle after the first which turned a staff into a nimble snake, to demonstrate the truth of his apostolate for the people he sent to him.
Allah did it all to show the proofs of the perfection of His power and the wonders of His deeds in the heavens and on earth.

After Allah showed signs of His power and greatness, He then ordered Moses to go to the cruel Pharaoh and invite him to worship Allah and threaten him with wrath and punishment from Allah if he disobeyed, and transgressed, rebellious and arrogant. he even dared to admit that he was a god with his words, "I am your high god." It was narrated from Wahb bin Munabbih that after the order came, Musa was silent for seven days thinking about the weight of the task assigned to him. After he was visited by an angel with the words, "Obey your Lord according to His commands," then he got up to carry out the order and hoped that Allah would expand his chest to be able to carry out his duties properly and bravely in facing Pharaoh. He feels that the burden that is carried on him is a big and very heavy matter, which cannot be carried out except with steady courage and an open chest. He was warned to face a king whose power was the greatest, most cruel, very disloyal, very many soldiers, prosperous in his kingdom, excessive in every way. The peak of that arrogance is that he knows no god but himself.

God's command to Moses to go and meet Pharaoh was a very difficult task, therefore Moses prayed and asked God to broaden his chest and strengthen his mind when he faced Pharaoh. God's Word: So that my chest feels tight and my tongue is not smooth, then Aaron sent (with me). (asy-Su'ara/26: 13) Besides that, he also asked Allah to make all his affairs easier, especially in conveying his apostolic news to Pharaoh, and to be given enough strength to be able to spread religion and improve the condition of the people, because without the help and Allah's help, Musa will not be able to do anything.

Musa asked that his tongue be eloquent and free, so that he could speak fluently and firmly, so that his listeners would easily digest and understand his words, so that they would receive God's guidance. For if Moses' tongue was mute, he would not speak fluently. The mufassir differed on the cause of Musa's eloquence, as follows: a. That when Musa was small, he pulled a hair from Pharaoh's chin, so Pharaoh became angry and he planned to vent his anger. Then he asked his wife to bring balah (raw dates) and a pile of burning coals. Pharaoh's wife defended Musa by saying, "Moses was still small, did not know anything." Even though there was a defense, Pharaoh still carried out his evil intentions, and the coal was placed on Moses' tongue. Since then Musa's tongue became stiff. Therefore Musa asked Allah to remove the confusion of his tongue. b. His tongue was caused by psychological factors that burdened Musa, as a result of his actions and deeds slapping and killing a Qibty. c. According to another opinion, that the confusion is congenital.

Because Musa felt that the task entrusted to him was quite big and heavy, he asked Allah to appoint a helper from his own family, to carry out da'wah together, sharing the fate and bearing in the ups and downs that his people would face.

This verse explains that Musa (pbuh) suggested that Aaron, his own brother who was older than him, be appointed as his assistant. the people of Egypt, a place to carry out his da'wah with Musa as, This act of Moses is a good thing to emulate and emulate, because a leader or ruler should have helpers to carry out their responsibilities, but of course good helpers who can be relied on for their good intentions in carrying out his duties as an assistant. The Prophet Muhammad himself had helpers as he said: Verily I have two helpers in the sky and two helpers on earth. As for my two helpers in the sky, Jibril and Mikail, and my two helpers on earth Abu Bakr and Umar. (History of al-hakim from Abi Sa'id)

Musa asked Allah, so that by appointing Harun as his assistant, it is hoped that he will increase his strength and abilities. Also so that Aaron is always with him in all his affairs, shoulder to shoulder in carrying out his heavy and holy task, so that he succeeds well, does not miss the intended target, and achieves the ideals that he desires properly.

In addition, so that he always remembers Allah, and always hopes for His pleasure.
